race.name: Iowa Wind and Rock
race.tagline: 340 miles of relentless Iowa gravel where the wind never stops, the terrain never flattens, and 40 hours of continuous riding reveals who you really are.

vitals.registration: Opens winter/early spring. Cost: ~$150-200. Iowa Gravel Series event.
vitals.aid_stations: None. Self-supported format. Resupply at Iowa small-town gas stations/stores (25-40 mi gaps).
vitals.cutoff_time: 50-60 hours from start (verify with organizer each year).

climate.primary: Unpredictable April Iowa weather with constant wind
climate.description: Mid-April brings 40-65°F daytime temperatures with 30-45°F overnight lows. April is wildly variable: snow, rain, or 70°F heat possible within same weekend. Rain risk 40-50%. Constant wind: 10-20 mph sustained, gusts to 30+ mph. Exposed farm roads offer no wind shelter. Severe weather risk (thunderstorms, tornadoes) during April. Mud conditions if rain turns fast Iowa gravel into unrideable peanut butter.
challenges: Wind is THE defining factor—headwinds for hours crush morale and slow speeds to 8-10 mph
April rain risk turns Iowa gravel into mud; bikes become unrideable
Cold overnight temperatures (30-45°F) for 30-50 hour efforts
Severe weather possible (thunderstorms, tornado warnings) force riders off course
Sun exposure during long daylight hours (15+ hours April daylight)

terrain.primary: Fast Iowa gravel with constant rolling undulation
terrain.surface: Crushed limestone gravel—hard-packed and fast when dry. Minimal technical terrain; Iowa county roads are maintained and smooth. Mud when wet (April rain common). Some paved connectors between gravel segments. Long straightaways on grid-pattern roads. 35-40mm tires sufficient when dry; 40-45mm if rain forecast for mud clearance. Tubeless mandatory.
features: Constant rolling terrain—short punchy climbs repeated over 340 miles
8,000 ft gain spread thin (24 ft/mile) but cumulative fatigue extreme
Exposed ridgelines and farm roads—zero wind shelter
River valley crossings (Des Moines, Middle, South Raccoon rivers)
Grid-pattern roads make navigation straightforward but easy to miss turns when fatigued
Farm dog encounters common in rural areas

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Ultra-endurance 340-mile format delivers massive adventure (5) and experience (5) scores. Length (5) is extreme. Low technicality (2) and elevation (2) offset by wind and weather (4). Limited prestige (2) holds back overall score.

biased_opinion.summary: Iowa Wind and Rock is 340 miles of truth serum on gravel. You can't hide behind teammates, tactics, or short bursts of power. This is 30-50 hours of continuous forward motion where the wind grinds you down, the constant rolling terrain never lets you recover, and your own brain becomes the biggest obstacle. The terrain itself isn't hard—Iowa gravel is fast when dry, and there are no mountains. But the wind is relentless. You'll spend hours grinding into headwinds at 8-10 mph, watching your finish time balloon, questioning why you signed up. Sleep deprivation hits around Hour 25-30. Navigation errors happen. The loneliness of self-supported racing amplifies every doubt. And April weather is a lottery: rain turns the course into mud hell, cold overnight temps test your layering strategy, or you luck out with mild sunny conditions. If you finish, you'll have earned something rare: proof that you can keep going when every external factor and internal voice says stop. If you DNF, you'll learn exactly where your limits are. Either outcome teaches you something.
strengths: 340 miles is genuine ultra-endurance challenge—tests limits beyond typical racing
Self-supported format teaches true independence and problem-solving under fatigue
Iowa Gravel Series organization provides solid GPS track and safety support
Resupply at Iowa small towns adds human connection and real-world adventure feel
Reasonable value ($150-200) for ultra-endurance format with tracking and finisher awards
weaknesses: Wind exposure for 30-50 hours is psychologically crushing—constant headwinds break morale
April weather unpredictability: rain/mud can make course unrideable, cold tests gear
340 miles is significantly longer than most ultras—bonking at Mile 200 leaves 140 miles remaining
Self-supported format means no external motivation, aid stations, or crowds—purely internal battle
Limited national prestige and small field depth—not attracting competitive racing atmosphere
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Iowa Wind and Rock rewards riders who value internal challenge and self-discovery over external validation. If you need crowds, frequent aid, or competitive atmosphere, skip it. If you want to discover what you're capable of when forced to grind through 340 miles of wind, darkness, and fatigue alone, this is your test. Budget 30-50 hours. Bring redundant everything. Accept that the finish line is about not quitting, not about speed.

course_description.character: Iowa Wind and Rock is 340 miles of honest Iowa gravel: crushed limestone roads rolling through endless agricultural land with zero shelter from wind. The terrain itself is moderate—8,000 feet of elevation spread thin via constant short climbs—but the format is brutal. You'll ride 30-50 hours continuously, crossing into overnight hours (often two nights for slower riders), navigating independently with GPS, and resupplying at small-town gas stations. The wind is THE defining feature: 10-20 mph sustained headwinds and crosswinds for hours. The constant rolling terrain means you never truly rest—always climbing or grinding into wind. River valley crossings add scenic variety and punchy elevation. The self-supported format strips away all external motivation. No crowds. No aid stations. No teammates. Just you, Iowa backroads, and the mental test of keeping pedals turning for 40+ hours when quitting would be easy.

suffering_zones.label: First Sunset Transition
suffering_zones.desc: Sun sets around Mile 80-90 for faster riders. Transition to first overnight. Reality of 250+ miles ahead sinks in. Temperature drops.

suffering_zones.label: Midnight Wind Tunnel
suffering_zones.desc: Deep into first overnight (or second day for slower riders). Coldest temps. Wind still blowing. Navigation errors when tired. Lowest morale point.

suffering_zones.label: The Void - Hour 35-40
suffering_zones.desc: Sleep deprivation peaks. Hallucinations possible. Questioning every life choice. Gas station stops become emotional lifelines. Mental survival mode.

suffering_zones.label: Zombie Finish Shuffle
suffering_zones.desc: Final 30 miles feel endless. Every small hill is a mountain. Bike handling skills decline. Grinding to finish line on pure stubbornness and fumes.

course_description.signature_challenge: Managing 30-50 hours of continuous riding while fighting relentless Iowa wind, sleep deprivation, and the psychological isolation of self-supported ultra-endurance racing with no external motivation.

logistics.airport: DSM (Des Moines) - 45min drive to Winterset. Rental car useful for area exploration and post-race flexibility.
logistics.lodging_strategy: Winterset, IA has limited motels/Airbnbs—book early. Des Moines (45 min) has more lodging options. Book flexible dates: finishers arrive Sunday-Monday depending on pace (30-50 hour range). Consider post-race recovery lodging for 1-2 nights.
logistics.food: Self-supported format: resupply at Iowa small-town gas stations and grocery stores (25-40 mi gaps). Bring cash—not all rural stores accept cards; some close early evening. Plan resupply stops using route map beforehand. Shelf-stable convenience store food becomes race fuel (hot dogs, pizza, candy, sports drinks).
logistics.packet_pickup: Friday evening or Saturday morning at Winterset start venue. GPS tracker required for safety monitoring.

history.origin_story: Iowa Wind and Rock was created as an ultra-endurance challenge within the Iowa Gravel Series, designed to test riders beyond typical 100-mile gravel races. The 340-mile self-supported format reflects Iowa's expansive agricultural landscape and the Midwest ethos of self-reliance. It attracts riders seeking genuine ultra-endurance adventure through Iowa's iconic gravel roads.
notable_moments: 2019: April weather brings rain and mud; many DNFs from unrideable conditions
2024: Continues as premier Iowa ultra-endurance gravel event
history.reputation: Respected regional ultra-endurance event known for wind, weather challenges, and genuine self-supported adventure through Iowa gravel roads.

community.vibe: Dedicated Iowa and Midwest ultra-endurance community. Grassroots organization values self-sufficiency and mental toughness. Small field of experienced self-supported racers who understand the challenge.
best_for: Experienced ultra-endurance riders ready for 340-mile self-supported format
Mentally tough athletes who thrive in isolation and don't need external motivation
Riders comfortable with wind, weather uncertainty, and 30-50 hour efforts
Self-sufficient athletes skilled at navigation, nutrition planning, and problem-solving under fatigue
not_for: First-time ultra-endurance riders—start with 100-200 mile events first
Riders needing frequent aid stations, crowds, or external motivation
Those uncomfortable with sleep deprivation and overnight solo riding
Athletes seeking competitive racing atmosphere and deep fields

key_workouts: Consecutive 200+ mile weekends to build ultra-endurance base
Long headwind training rides (4-6 hr into wind) to build mental toughness
Overnight practice rides (12-16 hr) to test nutrition and saddle time
Navigation training: practice GPS use, battery management, town-stop resupply
fitness_targets: 30-50 hour continuous effort capability—massive aerobic base required
Ability to process nutrition for 40+ hours without gastric shutdown
Mental resilience for sustained low-speed grinding (8-10 mph headwind efforts)
Sleep deprivation management: test power-through vs 2-hour nap strategy
equipment_priorities: Comfortable geometry gravel bike (340 miles = comfort over aero)
35-40mm tubeless tires (40-45mm if rain forecast for mud clearance)
Lighting: 1000+ lumen headlight + backup + dynamo hub ideal for ultra distance
Navigation: GPS device + phone backup + paper cues + extra battery packs
Bags: frame bags, top tube bag, saddle bag for nutrition/tools
Clothing: layering for 30-65°F range, rain jacket mandatory, extra gloves
Tools/spares: tubes, patch kit, chain links, derailleur hanger, spare brake pads (340 mi wears them)

race_day_tips: Download route + offline maps before start—cell service can be spotty
Program resupply town stops into GPS for easy navigation when fatigued
Bring phone charger + battery pack—charge at town stops
Weather forecast check: rain = bring extra tubes + bigger tires for mud clearance
Decide sleep strategy beforehand: power through 40+ hrs or strategic 2-hr nap (test in training)
Cash for small-town gas stations—not all accept cards; some close early
Pace conservatively first 100 miles—you have 240 miles ahead
Eat and hydrate proactively before hunger/thirst signals appear
Accept that wind will slow you down; don't fight the pace—manage morale instead

prestige.explanation: This is Iowa gravel ultra racing, not the Tour de France. 150-300 rider fields and minimal online chatter tell you everything about its place in the cycling hierarchy. It's a legitimate suffer-fest that builds character, but don't expect podium photos to impress anyone outside the ultra-endurance nerd circle.

race_quality.explanation: Self-supported format with GPS navigation and defined time limits shows proper race structure, but you're basically riding solo for 340 miles with gas station resupply. No aid stations, minimal support, and potential course reroutes for bridge closures keep this from premium territory. It's organized enough to function, raw enough to hurt.

experience.explanation: 340 miles through Iowa farmland will rewire your brain permanently. You'll hallucinate past Mile 230, question every life decision at 3 AM, and discover that gas station hot dogs are gourmet cuisine. The Madison County covered bridges and endless gravel grid roads create a uniquely American suffering experience that ultra-endurance addicts crave.

community.explanation: Small fields and self-supported format mean limited rider interaction during the event itself. The Iowa Gravel Series connection provides some regional community, but this isn't a social ride—you're mostly alone with your thoughts and the wind. What community exists is forged in shared suffering rather than post-race beer gardens.

field_depth.explanation: 150-300 riders willing to attempt 340 miles represents a tiny slice of cycling's lunatic fringe. The self-selected field of ultra-endurance masochists means everyone's legitimately tough, but the overall talent pool is narrow. This isn't where elite gravel racers come to test themselves—it's where normal people come to test their sanity.

value.explanation: $150-200 entry fee for 340 miles of organized suffering is solid economics—that's less than $0.60 per mile of existential crisis. Self-supported format means no fancy aid stations or swag, but you're paying for route planning, timing, and the privilege of pushing your limits in Iowa's agricultural vastness.

expenses.explanation: Winterset, Iowa isn't exactly a destination resort, so lodging and food costs stay reasonable for Midwest standards. You'll need serious lighting, navigation gear, and overnight clothing for the 30-50 hour effort, plus cash for gas station resupply runs. Budget accommodations exist, but gear requirements for ultra-endurance push total costs up.

length.explanation: 340 miles is legitimate ultra-endurance distance that separates pretenders from the genuinely unhinged. Most riders need 30-50 hours to finish, crossing multiple day/night cycles and entering sleep deprivation territory where hallucinations become navigation hazards. This isn't a long gravel race—it's a multi-day ordeal disguised as a single event.

technicality.explanation: Iowa gravel roads are fast, maintained crushed limestone through farmland—technical as a Walmart parking lot when dry. The challenge is endurance and navigation, not bike handling skills. When rain hits and turns everything to peanut butter mud, the technical difficulty spikes briefly, but mostly you're grinding straight roads through corn country.

elevation.explanation: 8,000 feet over 340 miles averages 24 feet per mile—barely noticeable individually but cumulatively brutal. Iowa's rolling farmland means constant undulation with no flat recovery sections, and river valley crossings add periodic legitimate climbs. By Mile 300, every gentle rise feels like a mountain when your legs are cooked.

climate.explanation: April in Iowa delivers the full Midwestern weather experience: 30-70°F temperature swings, constant 10-20 mph winds, and 40-50% rain probability that turns gravel to unrideable soup. The relentless wind exposure on endless farm roads becomes the defining challenge—headwinds for 50+ miles break souls. Add tornado season risk and overnight cold for true suffering variety.

altitude.explanation: Winterset, Iowa sits around 1,000 feet above sea level—altitude training for sea level dwellers. Oxygen isn't your limiting factor here, willpower is. The only thing thin at this elevation is your patience after 200 miles of Iowa wind.

logistics.explanation: Self-supported format puts logistics burden on riders—you handle navigation, nutrition, and mechanicals solo for 340 miles. Small Iowa towns provide resupply every 25-40 miles, but stores close early and not all take cards. GPS tracks are provided and time limits enforced, but bridge closures and road reroutes happen without warning in rural Iowa.

adventure.explanation: 340 miles alone on Iowa gravel roads pushes you into legitimate adventure territory where things can go genuinely wrong. Navigation errors in the grid road system, severe weather encounters, and 40+ hours of sleep deprivation create real consequences. You'll discover parts of Iowa most people never see and parts of yourself you'd rather forget.

final_verdict.one_liner: 340 miles of Iowa gravel where the wind never stops and the suffering compounds every hour you're out there.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need 200+ mile experience and the mental fortitude to grind through 40+ hours of constant wind exposure across endless farm roads. This isn't about watts—it's about navigation skills, self-sufficiency, and accepting that you'll question every life choice around Mile 200. Skip it if you've never done overnight riding or think Iowa looks flat and easy.
final_verdict.alternatives: Dirty Kanza DK200 gives you the ultra-endurance challenge with better support and more prestige, while Gravel Worlds in Nebraska delivers similar Midwest suffering with a more established field. Both will test you without the navigation headaches of true self-support.
